questions.text: What should raise a red flag when Alex receives an email asking for his bank details?

options.text: The urgent request for sensitive information.
The email includes a greeting by name.

questions.description: Phishing emails often create a sense of urgency to trick the recipient into quickly divulging sensitive information without proper verification.

questions.text: Why was the email Alex received considered a phishing attempt?

options.text: It was sent outside of business hours.
It did not come from Anita’s official "involead" email domain.
It was sent to multiple recipients.

questions.description: A key indicator of a phishing email is the sender's email address not matching the official domain of the organization they claim to represent.

questions.text: Which characteristic of phishing emails was highlighted by the scam email pretending to be from HR?

options.text: Requests for immediate action or sharing of personal information.
Providing a contact number for queries.
Mentioning the company’s name several times.

questions.description: Urgent requests for action or personal information are tactics used by scammers to pressure victims into making hasty decisions.

questions.text: What is the best practice when you receive an email that seems suspicious or asks for sensitive information?

options.text: Reply with the requested information if the sender appears to be someone you know.
Ignore the email completely and do not inform anyone.
Verify the sender’s email address and contact the supposed sender through a different communication channel to confirm the request.
Forward the email to your friends to see if they received a similar one.

questions.description: Verifying the authenticity of the request through a different communication channel is a safe practice to avoid falling for phishing scams.
